awd_titl_txt: Globalizing Cultural Psychology: Varieties of Interdependence Across Four Regions of the World
awd_abstract_narration:
In the increasingly global world, it is important to understand other cultural groups.  Such understanding will be helpful in peacefully addressing world conflicts, negotiating business deals, and facilitating group interactions.  Westerners see themselves as independent agents, and they are individualistic in value. In contrast, some non-Western groups, such as people in Asia, and possibly those in Arab regions, Africa, and Latin America, often see themselves as interdependent with others in their groups and relations. They tend to be more collectivistic. This project investigates the ways that different non-Western groups develop their cultural styles of interdependence by utilizing different strategies of attaining this valued state. It is hypothesized, for example, that East Asians achieve interdependence by avoiding conflicts with others and attain social harmony within their groups. Arab people, on the other hand, do so by self-assertively resolving conflicts with others and by protecting their groups. By studying multiple cultural groups, we may be able to learn more about non-Western and Western cultures. Thus, this project can learn how Westerners typically assert themselves to express their individuality so that they can feel more esteemed and independent. 

To test this framework, six studies will be conducted to identify the nuances involved in the interdependence-independence construct. The studies will assess three core features of interdependence vs. independence, including the primacy of personal versus social goals as predictors of happiness, analytic versus holistic attention, and analytic versus holistic social cognition. The research will also assess three pairs of subsidiary features that theoretically produce different styles of interdependence. In particular, the use of self-effacement vs. assertion, emotional suppression vs. expression, and dialectic vs. logical reasoning, can all produce different types of interdependence. Those strategies often arise from the ecological context of the cultures. Highly populated cites with greater commerce, for example, should produce more argumentative interdependence whereas more linguistically diverse areas should produce more emotional expressivity. The subsidiary features will be measured across a set of 16 cultural groups from South Asia, Central Asia, East Asia, and across the Middle East, Africa, Western Europe, Latin America, and those groups will be contrasted to groups in North America. It is expected that there will be a broad divergence between the groups regarding the strategies they use to achieve their desired cultural state of independence and interdependence. It is also predicted that the West will differ from the non-West in core features while the non-West will be characterized relatively more in subsidiary features. Experimental tests will include priming manipulations designed to produce independence or interdependence to test their later effects on the subsidiary features. Results will shed light on how cultural groups utilize social interaction styles to produce independence and interdependence. This project will facilitate our understanding of intercultural interactions and provide a more comprehensive view of human psychology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project aimed to explore the cultural diversity beyond the traditional Western-dominated framework in social psychology. By examining non-Western regions—including Latin America, South Asia, and Sub-Saharan Africa—we sought to uncover variations in interdependence and collectivism that go beyond the “East vs. West” dichotomy. Our findings significantly contribute to broadening the theoretical scope of social psychology and fostering a more globalized perspective.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit

The project identified that while interdependence and collectivism are common across many non-Western cultures, they manifest in distinct ways influenced by each region's ecological, historical, and geographic factors. For example:

  • In Latin America, individuals in countries like Chile, Colombia, and Mexico express positive emotions, such as compassion, in response to others’ negative experiences. This reflects an emotionally expressive form of interdependence that prioritizes relational harmony.
  • In Arab cultures, high levels of self-enhancement are observed, similar to Western cultures. However, unlike Westerners, who typically exhibit self-enhancement for personal independence, Arabs demonstrate this trait in the context of strengthening group ties. This shows that self-enhancement, typically viewed as a Western trait, can be reinterpreted as a marker of interdependence.
  • South Asian cultures emphasize logical reasoning. Individuals in this region are committed to using category-based information, often sidelining everyday “commonsense” in favor of formal logic. This contrasts with East Asian cultures, which rely heavily on commonsense over strict logical reasoning.
  • In Sub-Saharan Africa, we observed that the pursuit of personal goals is embedded within a collective framework. Africans often express pride and connection simultaneously upon success, regardless of whether it is personal or collective, suggesting a deep social embeddedness in personal achievements.

These findings challenge established assumptions in social psychology, which often link traits like analytic cognition and self-enhancement solely with independence. By showing that such traits can align with interdependence in non-Western contexts, the project decouples these traits from Western individualism, opening new avenues for research on cultural diversity in psychology.

Broader Impacts and Global Relevance

This research is pivotal for the ongoing effort to diversify psychology. Historically, over 90% of psychological research has relied on WEIRD populations, raising concerns about the generalizability of its findings. By investigating cultural zones that have been underrepresented, this project provides an essential corrective to this imbalance, underscoring the need to include diverse populations in psychological research.

Beyond academia, the project also engages with broader issues of global diversity and inclusion. While diversity initiatives often focus on local issues within Western countries, our findings highlight a global disparity in psychological research. The project advocates for including insights from non-Western regions to inform theories in psychology, advancing a truly inclusive approach.

Dissemination and Professional Development

The findings have been widely disseminated through academic publications in prestigious journals like American Psychologist and Annual Review of Psychology, as well as presentations at major conferences such as the Society for Personality and Social Psychology (SPSP) and the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology (IACCP). Additionally, workshops, webinars, and public outreach activities have engaged diverse audiences, from academic researchers to the general public.

The project also provided valuable professional development opportunities. Team members received training in cross-cultural research methodologies, advanced data analysis, and interdisciplinary collaboration. These experiences have equipped them to carry forward the project’s mission of fostering a culturally sensitive approach to psychology.

Conclusion

In summary, this project has made substantial contributions to the field of social psychology by revealing the diverse forms of interdependence across non-Western cultures. It challenges the dominance of Western-centric perspectives, proposing instead that many psychological traits considered “universal” are deeply influenced by cultural context. By broadening the scope of social psychology, this work not only advances our theoretical understanding but also sets a foundation for future research that truly represents the diversity of human experience.
